awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Evolutionary Origins of Theory of Mind: Computational Modeling of Conserved Cognitive Mechanisms Across Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Laurie Santos and Dr. Julian Jara-Ettinger at Yale University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating how humans and non-human primates understand the minds of others. As humans, understanding what other people think, feel, desire, and believe is central to successfully navigating our social world. However, we still know little about the extent to which our ability to represent others’ mental states is shared with other animals, impeding our understanding of human cognitive evolution and slowing the development of treatments for mental disorders involving deficits in these skills.

Deficits in theory of mind (ToM) are core components of developmental and neuropsychiatric disorders including autism spectrum disorder, antisocial personality disorder, and schizophrenia, and have profound effects on social relationships, effective communication, and moral reasoning. Animal models have recently advanced our understanding of the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying diseases that affect social decision-making (e.g., Parkinson’s disease) and approaches for their treatment. However, outstanding questions about the cognitive mechanisms underlying primates’ ToM judgments have impeded the development of an animal model of ToM. This project draws on computational methods developed for modeling human ToM to overcome these challenges. By computationally modeling non-human primate (NHP) ToM for the first time, this project will elucidate which cognitive mechanisms humans and NHPs share when making judgments about others’ mental states. Additionally, the fellow will computationally identify new experimental designs that can powerfully distinguish between competing representational hypotheses about NHP ToM and will test free-ranging rhesus macaques to empirically evaluate these designs. This work will (1) contribute to our fundamental understanding of the evolution of ToM and the cognitive mechanisms that guide social behavior and (2) advance a NHP model of human ToM which will aid in our understanding and treatment of ToM-related mental disorders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding what other people think, feel, desire, and believe is central to the way humans successfully navigate the social world. Our theory of mind (ToM) allows us to understand the connection between others' mental states and their behavior, playing a central role in our social interactions. Therefore, ToM-related deficits can have deep and enduring effects on individuals' formation and maintenance of social relationships, ability to communicate effectively, and moral reasoning. Unfortunately, we still know little about the extent to which our ability to represent others' mental states is shared with other animals. Key unanswered questions remain about the specific cognitive mechanisms that non-human primates (1) use to predict what others might do based on what they can see, what they know, or what they believe and (2) use to draw inferences about the mental states that underlie observed behavior. These decades-old questions have impeded our understanding of human cognitive evolution and slowed the development animal models to advance treatments for mental disorders involving deficits in these skills.

This project aimed to identify how humans and non-human primates represent others' mental states, and how these representations guide social behavior. To do so, we leveraged computational methods developed for modeling ToM in humans to overcome challenges in the field of comparative psychology. Building computational models of different representational accounts of non-human primate ToM allowed us to illuminate the unstated assumptions that accompany many previously proposed verbal theories and to detect subtle differences in social behavior that might arise based on different theories. Therefore, the major goals of the project were realized through (1) building and evaluating the first computational models of ToM in non-human primates and (2) collecting new cognitive/behavioral data on ToM in rhesus macaques via fieldwork.

Regarding the former, we built and assessed computational models that sought to explain how non-human primates behave in previously published perspective-taking experiments. More specifically, we built seven different computational models using probabilistic Markov Decision Processes (MDPs), each representing a different theory of non-human primate ToM. We then compared each of these seven models against non-human primates' observed performance across five different experimental paradigms, drawing on data from 10+ previously published experiments. Regarding the latter, we collected new data on non-human primate ToM in the field via behavioral experiments with 450+ free-ranging rhesus macaques.

Our results support the idea that limited 'mentalistic' mechanisms best predict non-human primate perspective-taking behavior rather than more sophisticated human-like ToM mechanisms. We also find that simpler mechanisms, including those that reason only about others' behavior (but not mental states) and those that use rigid behavioral rules, are not able to explain non-human primates' behavior in perspective-taking experiments. Finally, our work formalized a previously underappreciated parameter of non-human primate theory of mind -- how often non-human primates can successfully deploy their ToM representations in social tasks -- and also provides a framework for other scholars to computationally formalize and test competing theories of ToM in non-human animals.

This project resulted in multiple conference presentations, one manuscript submitted to a peer-reviewed journal, and another manuscript in preparation. In sum, our work advanced the development of an animal model of ToM by providing a more complete understanding of which aspects of human ToM that non-human primates share with us, and which they do not.
